Petrarch met him in Florence in 1350, and -b-o-rrowed from him three of Ciceroâ€™s speeches, the Pro Sulla, Pro Plancio, and Pro Lege Manilia. These appear to have been sent on to him afterwards together with a fourth, the Pro Milone, and in Fam. vii. 15 (April 1351), he thanks Lapo for the receipt of the manuscripts. He also received a Quintilian from Lapo, and later sent him a copy of the Pro Archia, which he had found at Liege in 1333 (cf. Sen. xvi. 1). Fam. xix. 2 [1354]

PAGE 107. For Zanobi da Strada see Fam. xv. 3. He was now at Naples in the service of the Grand Seneschal, Niccolo Acciaiuoli. The Emperor Charles IV was now in Italy. In Fam. xix. 1 Petrarch writes to congratu- late him on his arriva13 he then visited him at Mantua at the express invitation of the Emperor. In a letter to his friend Laelius, Fam. xix. 3, Petrarch relates the conversation they had together, and the great interest Charles showed in his book, the De Viris Illustribus. For Charles IV see the note to Fam. xii. 1.

Fam. xix. 9 [24 April 1355]

Faliero had been angered by the slight penalty inflicted on a young nobleman who had insulted his wife, and together with a sea captain, who had his own reasons for hating the government, plotted to overthrow the aristocratic constitution.
